question.direction-text: Select the appropriate phrases from the answer choices and match them to the type of aphasia to which they relate. TWO of the answer choices will NOT be used. This question is worth 3 points.

answer-text.exp: Often makes it difficult for a sufferer to understand others

answer.explain-text: The passage states that a person who suffers from fluent aphasia…tends not to understand what others are saying. This means that fluent aphasia often makes it difficult for a sufferer to understand others. This answer should therefore be used to describe fluent aphasia.

answer-text.exp: Is used in a different way from its literal meaning of "without speech"

answer.explain-text: The passage states that though aphasia literally means "without speech," it is often used in reference to the disorder suffered by people whose speech is problematic. The answer choice is used in a different way from its literal meaning of "without speech" is true information from the passage, but it is information that is not critical to the differentiation between agrammatism and fluent aphasia, so this is not a correct answer choice.

answer-text.exp: Can result from damage to an area of the brain in front of and above the left ear

answer.explain-text: The passage states that Paul Broca indicated an area in the brain in front of and slightly above the left ear…that damage to this general region of the brain is likely to result in severe speech problems; as a result, agrammatic speech is sometimes known as Broca's aphasia. From this, it can be determined that agrammatism can result from damage to an area of the brain in front of and above the left ear. This answer should therefore be used to describe agrammatism.

answer-text.exp: Makes it difficult for someone to speak fluently

answer.explain-text: The passage states that agrammatism is the technical term for one type of aphasic condition in which people have difficulty stringing words together into sentences. This means that agrammatism makes it difficult for someone to speak fluently. This answer should therefore be used to describe agrammatism.

answer-text.exp: Does not generally inhibit the ability to speak fluently

answer.explain-text: The passage states that a person who suffers from fluent aphasia can speak quite fluently. This means that fluent aphasia does not generally inhibit the ability to speak fluently. This answer should therefore be used to describe fluent aphasia.

answer-text.exp: Always results from damage to the left side of the brain

answer.explain-text: The passage states that it is not always the case that brain damage to a particular spot in the brain automatically results in a particular speech disorder. This means that it is NOT true that either agrammatism or fluent aphasia always results from damage to the left side of the brain, so this is not a correct answer choice.

answer-text.exp: Does not generally inhibit understanding of others

answer.explain-text: The passage mentions agrammatism and states that someone with this condition can generally understand what others say quite well. This means agrammatism does not generally inhibit understanding of others. This answer should therefore be used to describe agrammatism.

answer-text.exp: Can result from damage to an area in the back of the brain and under the left ear

answer.explain-text: The passage states that a number of patients who suffered from fluent aphasia had severe brain damage toward the back of the brain, in an area under the left ear. This means that fluent aphasia can result from damage to an area in the back of the brain and under the left ear. This answer should therefore be used to describe fluent aphasia.
